title: 110_hr5659
content: Section 46 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new paragraph for the reclamation credit. Additionally, a new section 48C is added for recycling or remanufacturing equipment. The reclamation credit under section 46 allows for a 20 percent credit on the basis of qualified reclamation property placed in service during the taxable year. Qualified reclamation property includes tangible property with a useful life of at least 5 years, acquired by purchase, and eligible for depreciation or amortization. The reclamation credit allows for a 20 percent credit on qualified reclamation property with a useful life of at least 5 years, acquired by purchase or constructed by the taxpayer. The basis of such property for any taxable year is limited to $10,000,000 per taxpayer, with controlled group members treated as one taxpayer. The Secretary will apportion the dollar limitation among the group. The dollar limitation for the reclamation credit applies to controlled group members as one taxpayer. Partnerships and S corporations are subject to the limitation, with rules similar to those for individuals. The term 'controlled group' is defined as per section 1563(a), with 'more than 50 percent' replacing 'at least 80 percent'. Rules similar to subsections (c)(4) and (d) of section 46 apply for qualified recycling and remanufacturing property definitions. Qualified recycling property includes equipment for collecting, distributing, or sorting ferrous or nonferrous metals, excluding precious metals like gold, silver, or platinum unless coincidental to other metal sorting. Qualified remanufacturing property refers to equipment used in rebuilding or remanufacturing products with 50% or less virgin material. The equipment must not be used primarily after the rebuilding process. This section coordinates with rehabilitation and energy credits. The text chunk discusses amendments to the tax code related to energy property and investment credits. It includes changes to the basis adjustment rule and a clerical amendment to the table of sections. Amendments made to the tax code regarding energy property and investment credits, including changes to the basis adjustment rule and a clerical amendment to the table of sections. Effective January 1, 2007, the amendments apply to property placed in service.
